data: A plaque of Sicilian white limestone, intact except at the upper right corner.
Seven lines of Greek letters, filling the face, with a regular left margin, the final line approximately centred; the text is engraved by means of individual dots punched with a rounded tool.

Regular neatly cut letters, with pronounced terminations to the strokes. Alpha has broken bar; beta a much smaller upper eye, just closed; epsilon has nearly equal strokes; zeta formed by vertical with horizontal top and bottom; kappa has shortened arms; mu has midstrokes descending only half-way, curved rather than angular, and not always reaching the top of the verticals; xsi formed by three horizontals only, the middle one shorter; omicron is full size; pi has horizontal extending beyond the verticals; sigma has horizontal top and bottom strokes; phi is standard height, with ovoid eye; omega is closed, and tear-drop shaped.
Later second or earlier first century BCE
Found in excavations of the so-called 'Gymnasium' (a private house) in 1865, at Solunto
On display on the wall of the courtyard of the Museo Archeologico Regionale Antonino Salinas
Partially reopened following extensive restoration work. Comprehensive collection of archaeological material, predominantly from the West of the island, with an important Etruscan collection.
Centre of Palermo, Piazza Olivella 24, 90100 - Palermo
F. Bechtel et al., Sammlung der griechischen Dialekt-Inschriften, 4 vols (Göttingen: Vandenhoeck and Ruprecht, 1884)
De la Sicile à l'Égypte: les noms ORNIXAS, ORNITHAS et le substantif ORNITHAS
Olivier Masson, « De la Sicile à l’Égypte: les noms ORNIXAS, ORNITHAS et le substantif ORNITHAS », Chronique d’Égypte 97 (1974): 175‑78
La ginnasiarchia nelle "poleis" dell'occidente mediterraneo antico
G. Cordiano, La ginnasiarchia nelle «poleis» dell’occidente mediterraneo antico, Studi e testi di storia antica 7 (Pisa, 1997)
Problemi dell'archeologia della Sicilia ellenistico-romana: il caso di Solunto
Elisa Chiara Portale, «Problemi dell’archeologia della Sicilia ellenistico-romana: il caso di Solunto», Archeologia Classica 57 (2006): 49–114
Scavi e scoperte. Posizione topografica di Solunto
S. Cavallari, «Scavi e scoperte. Posizione topografica di Solunto», Bullettino della Commissione di Antichità e belle arti di Sicilia 8 (1875): 1–10
Auxilia and gymnasia: a Sicilian model of Roman Republican Imperialism
J.R.W. Prag, ‘Auxilia and Gymnasia: A Sicilian Model of Roman Republican Imperialism’, Journal of Roman Studies 97 (2007): 68–100
Jonathan Prag edited metadata and added image
Masson, 1974, De la Sicile à l'Égypte: les noms ORNIXAS, ORNITHAS et le substantif ORNITHAS
Cordiano, 1997, La ginnasiarchia nelle "poleis" dell'occidente mediterraneo antico

Text of IGPalermo controlled against photograph

English translation

Jonathan Prag

The three units of infantry who served at the time of Apollonios son of Apollonios, and the ephebes of his year (honour) Antallos Ornichas, son of Antallos, grandson of Antallos who held the office of gymnasiarch, for the sake of good will.

Seven lines of Greek letters, filling the face, with a regular left margin, the final line approximately centred; the text is engraved by means of individual dots punched with a rounded tool.

Regular neatly cut letters, with pronounced terminations to the strokes. Alpha has broken bar; beta a much smaller upper eye, just closed; epsilon has nearly equal strokes; zeta formed by vertical with horizontal top and bottom; kappa has shortened arms; mu has midstrokes descending only half-way, curved rather than angular, and not always reaching the top of the verticals; xsi formed by three horizontals only, the middle one shorter; omicron is full size; pi has horizontal extending beyond the verticals; sigma has horizontal top and bottom strokes; phi is standard height, with ovoid eye; omega is closed, and tear-drop shaped.
